description:
Game & Watch: Ball, also known as Toss-Up in the USA ("Time Out series" by MEGO), is the first in a long series of Nintendo electronic games. This game belongs to the first series, also known as the "Silver Series". Originally Ball should have been called Acrobat, hence the serial name AC-01.

The small character in the game has to juggle two balls, moving his arms from right to left. Although slow at first, the pace progressively goes faster, challenging the player's reflexes and sense of rhythm. In game B, the player has to juggle three balls instead of two. Failing to catch one ball will have a "crush" appear on the screen, automatically ending the game.
title: Game & Watch: Ball

description:
Game & Watch: Flagman, also known as Flag Man (two words) in the USA in the Time Out series by MEGO, is the first of the Game & Watch models to offer two games in one, which didn't just differ from each other by speeding up the game for an advanced difficulty. The second G&W game to appear in the so-called Silver Series.

In game A, the player has to use his or her memory by repeating a sequence of numbers appearing at the on-screen character; numbers 1 and 2 are on flags behind his back and numbers 3 and 4 are on both his feet. Each number has its corresponding sound/volume pitch. Game B is a game of reflexes where the player has to push the right button asked by the onscreen character as quick as possible.
title: Game & Watch: Flagman

description:
The Arcade Portable is a Genesis/Mega Drive handheld console on a chip originally produced by AtGames. It has a 2.4" LCD display, a menu button, a start/select button, a d-pad and three action buttons like the original Genesis/Mega Drive controller. It has a built-in speaker with volume control and outputs for headphones and for composite AV cable. It comes with 20 built-in games, with no option for expanding the catalogue. The included games are:

  • Alex Kidd in the Enchanted Castle
  • Alien Storm
  • Altered Beast
  • Arrow Flash
  • Columns III: Revenge of Columns
  • Crack Down
  • DEcapAttack
  • Dr. Robotnik's Mean Bean Machine
  • E-Swat: City Under Siege
  • Ecco the Dolphin
  • Ecco Jr.
  • Flicky
  • Gain Ground
  • Golden Axe
  • Jewel Master
  • Kid Chameleon
  • Ristar
  • Shadow Dancer: The Secret of Shinobi
  • Sonic & Knuckles
  • The Revenge of Shinobi
title: The Arcade Portable

description: This is the second version of the Cyber Poké Ball, a simple RPG set in the Pokémon universe and contained within a handheld shaped like a Poké Ball. The units come in several colors and patterns. In the game, players explore a map to find wild Pokémon and battle them. A weakened wild Pokémon can be captured and added to the party; the player may own a maximum of three Pokémon at a time. Pokémon automatically evolve upon reaching certain level thresholds. Players may challenge area bosses, which will grant access to new parts of the world upon their defeat. They may also use the device's connectivity features to battle other nearby players. Special chips, which came packaged with various Pokémon toys made by Bandai, could be inserted into the device in order to access new content.
title: Pokémon Advanced: Cyber Poké Ball 2

description:
This iteration of the Tamagotchi virtual pet sticks to the same general formula as its predecessors; the player is charged with caring for a virtual creature and attending to its needs. This includes feeding the pet, cleaning up after its messes, giving it discipline and praise as appropriate, and keeping it entertained with games. The pet starts off as an egg, and will progress through several stages of life until it dies or reproduces. Depending on the creature's gender and how well it is cared for, it may develop into a number of different forms as it grows older.

This Tamagotchi release is the first one to allow multiplayer, which is accomplished by connecting two devices via the infrared port on top. The two Tamagotchi pets will then either exchange gifts, or play a competitive mini-game against each other. Afterwards, the two will be registered into one another's friend lists. The more two specific pets connect with one another, the more affection will build between them. Two adults of the opposite gender may fall in love and produce offspring if they reach a high enough affection level. At that point, the adult creatures will disappear, leaving the players to care for the new babies.
title: Tamagotchi Connection

description:
Game & Watch: Vermin, also known as The Exterminator in the USA in the Time Out series by MEGO, is the third game in the Silver Series and the first G&W game to introduce the concept of three lives, which became the norm in the vast majority of LCD electronic titles around the world. Originally Vermin would have been called "Mogura Tataki" (Whacking Moles), hence the serial name MT-03.

Designed to play like the popular "Whack-A-Mole" game from the arcades it's the player's mission to whack the moles coming from the bottom part of the screen appearing in 5 different spots. The goal is hitting them on the head as fast as possible, before the moles run away and passing the player, resulting in a "MISS". Failing three times will end up in a "Game Over". The controls are simple movements to the left and right, taking into consideration the wingspan of the on-screen character. Hammering the moles is done automatically when their heads appear under your hammer.
title: Game & Watch: Vermin

description:
Game & Watch: Fire, also known as Fireman Fireman in the USA in the Time Out series by MEGO, is the fourth game in the Silver Series and the first G&W game to introduce the option to save your best score. This score can be displayed by pressing the Game A or Game B button, however it will be lost on a battery change or system reset.

The concept of the game is to guide the medics with their stretcher who have to catch people falling from different floors of a building on fire. In Game A the player needs to time the bouncing of the victims on the stretcher just right, like a trampoline, until they fall directly into the ambulance. In Game B, the goal stays the same, but the player has to deal with 9 bouncing people at the time.
title: Game & Watch: Fire

description:
This is the first game in the Tamagotchi series, and contains the majority of the series' basic gameplay elements. The player is tasked with caring for a virtual pet that is said to have come from a distant planet. This includes feeding the pet, cleaning up after its messes, giving it discipline and praise as appropriate, and keeping it entertained with games. The pet starts off as an egg, and will progress through several stages of life until it dies. Depending on how well the creature is cared for, it may develop into a number of different forms as it grows older.

This version of Tamagotchi had two releases, which are colloquially referred to as P1 and P2, or as Generations 1 and 2. The differences between the two releases are which minigame is available, which background the screen has, and the available characters. However, all other gameplay elements are the exact same between versions.
title: Tamagotchi

description:
Tamagotchi Angel is a version of the virtual pet series in which the player is responsible for caring for a celestial being during its time on Earth. The gameplay is similar to other Tamagotchis, but with a few twists that reflect the pet's nature as an angel. One such feature is Angel Power, or AP, which increases when the pet is fed, and can decrease if the pet is neglected or the player fails to administer praise at the proper times. AP helps determine which evolution path the pet will take. In this version, there is no discipline option, but the pet must be praised whenever the player notices it praying.

The device includes sound and motion sensors. At times, the pet may go for a stroll, during which time it will disappear from the screen and be unavailable for interaction. Although the pet will eventually return on its own, it can be called back early by simultaneously using the praise option and activating one of the sensors. The motion sensor is also used to scare away bats, which occasionally appear to steal the pet's food during meal times.
title: Tamagotchi Angel

description: This Tamagotchi virtual pet is focused solely on raising male pets, and is the counterpart to Tamagotchi Mesutchi. For the most part, the pet is cared for in all the standard ways. However, once it reaches adulthood, it can be physically linked up with a Tamagotchi Mesutchi in order for the two pets to breed and produce offspring. The results of breeding are based on the pets' Tamagotchi Mating Power, or TMP, which is primarily determined by how well the pet was cared for during its lifespan.
title: Tamagotchi Osutchi

description:
Game & Watch: Judge is the fifth and final Game & Watch game in the Silver Series and the first ever LCD electronic game to ever allow for two players to play simultaneously.

The previous game Game & Watch: Fire was also the last game that the US company MEGO published, after which Nintendo of America decided to take care of the G&W internally and re-design the packaging, to make them more appealing to the public, hence the Pocket-size game line started.

The game can be played in two player mode or single player mode and starts with two characters facing each other in a duel of focus and reflexes. The player needs to wait for the two to each lift a sign reading a random number from 1 to 9. In single-player, if your player character shows a higher number than the CPU's, then you must push the hit button. If yours is the lower number however, then you must push the dodge/flee button. If you manage to hit your opponent before he could dodge or avoid his attack, you will score points. Game B is used for playing against a fellow person instead of a CPU.
title: Game & Watch: Judge

description: This Tamagotchi virtual pet is focused solely on raising female pets, and is the counterpart to Tamagotchi Osutchi. For the most part, the pet is cared for in all the standard ways. However, once it reaches adulthood, it can be physically linked up with a Tamagotchi Osutchi in order for the two pets to breed and produce offspring. The results of breeding are based on the pets' Tamagotchi Mating Power, or TMP, which is primarily determined by how well the pet was cared for during its lifespan.
title: Tamagotchi Mesutchi

description: Mori de Hakken!! Tamagotchi is a virtual pet game in which the player is charged with caring for an insectoid Tamagotchi creature. The normal care options, such as feeding the pet and cleaning up after it, are present, and there are several options unique to this Tamagotchi as well. Occasionally the pet will be threatened by a predator, which the player must scare away by activating the device's motion sensor. In addition, the life cycle of the pet includes a cocoon stage. During this time, the only care option is temperature, which needs to be monitored throughout the day and adjusted as necessary. The cocoon's temperature can rise and fall without the player's input, and can potentially kill the pet if it remains too hot or too cold for an extended amount of time. The average temperature maintained during this stage influences the pet's evolution path.
title: Mori de Hakken!! Tamagotchi

description:
Game & Watch Gold: Manhole is the first game in the second series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Gold Series. The gold series is also the first G&W series to feature the kickstand/"crutch" for people who wanted to use the alarm/clock functions of the G&W games.

The gameplay features a character, using simple plates, to help people crossing the road unharmed at two different heights/levels. With time the frequency of people and their speed will increase. Game B, doesn't set itself apart from Game A, apart from more people crossing the roads at the beginning and a quicker onset of pace and frequency of people. The game Manhole is the first G&W to ever feature an extra live bonus system. Every 200 or 500 points (depending on the game-type), a little tune will indicate that one or more "misses" will be forgiven.
title: Game & Watch Gold: Manhole

description:
Game & Watch Gold: Helmet is the second game in the second series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Gold Series. Due to an inappropriate slang meaning in the United Kingdom, it was renamed Headache in CGL version.

The character on-screen has to evade thrown tools from the level above and to reach the shelter on the right side of the screen, which opens on an irregular basis. Game B quickens the tempo at which speed the tools drop from above and the locker room stays open for a shorter period of time.
title: Game & Watch Gold: Helmet

description:
Game & Watch Gold: Lion is the third and last game in the second series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Gold Series. Lion used, for the first time, the concept of little animated cut scenes. When the lion escaped the guard would be seen running and climbing on top of the tree.

A vaguely similar concept to Manhole, where the goal was to protect pedestrians on two levels, Lion requires simultaneous interaction with 6 open cages with two guards, armed with only chairs. The chair is simply used to push the animal back, whilst the cage stays and keeps open. In game B three lions, instead of the two lions in game A, need to be dealt with. The game can be played by two players simultaneously, with each controlling one side.
title: Game & Watch Gold: Lion

description:
Tamagotchi Ocean is a virtual pet game in which the player is charged with caring for an aquatic Tamagotchi creature. The normal care options, such as feeding the pet and cleaning up after it, are present, and there are several options unique to this Tamagotchi as well. Occasionally the pet will be threatened by a predator, which the player must scare away by activating the device's motion sensor. In addition, the player needs to pay attention to the water quality. The water becomes dirtier over time, and needs to be cleaned periodically in order to keep the pet healthy.

This Tamagotchi is one of the more difficult ones to raise to adulthood, due to it requiring very diligent care. International releases in particular tend to have very short lifespans.
title: Tamagotchi Ocean

description: This is a caveman-themed Tamagotchi inspired by the 1997 film Peking Man. Aside from the prehistoric theme, the primary distinguishing feature of this Tamagotchi is that it is very high maintenance and requires near-constant care. If neglected for too long, it is even capable of devolving into an earlier stage of life.
title: Genjintchi no Tamagotchi

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Parachute is the first game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series.

Characters on parachutes are dropped on-screen by helicopters into the sea swarming with sharks. The players mission is to row left and right to intercept these said parachutists from an untimely death. The higher the score the more lives you have to save with up to ten characters at a time. Failing to rescue a parachutist will trigger a scene where the character is eaten by the sharks. Game B will up the ante with parachutists getting stuck in the palm tree in the lower right corner, swinging dangerously above the sea.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Parachute

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Octopus is the second game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series.

In this game, one has to guide three explorers equipped with old-fashioned scuba gear pass a waiting octopus to get a hold of the sacks of gold hidden in a shipwreck. The player has to get as much gold as he can without getting touched by the giant squid. If the latter touches the character he's immediately captured by it. Game B is not much different only an increase of speed and therefore the difficulty.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Octopus

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Popeye is the third game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series. Popeye is the first third party licensed character to be used by Nintendo in a G&W.

One plays as Popeye the sailor, needing to catch objects thrown from the wharf by Olive Oil. If the player misses one, it falls into the sea, which results in half a miss. At certain points Bluto will be trying to punch Popeye as he appears from the left side of the screen. If Bluto hits Popeye he will fall into the water and lose a life. In Game B Bluto can appear from both sides of the screen.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Popeye

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Chef is the fourth game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series. Chef was supposed to be named Food Panic, hence the serial name FP-24.

The player controls a chef juggling around the food so that nothing touches the floor. If something does touches the floor, a mouse will pick it up and counts as a miss. Three misses will count as a game over. At irregular intervals a cat in the upper left corner will suspend a certain food item, making it harder for the player to guess which piece is flippable. Game B will have the player juggle four items, instead of the three in Game A.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Chef

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Mickey Mouse is the fifth game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series.

The player controls Mickey Mouse as he tries to catch the eggs rolling from four different hen houses. If one is not fast enough then that egg will fall down and break. The game features four buttons, one for each spot where Mickey can put his basket. Sometimes Minnie Mouse shows up above the scenery and, if an egg breaks while she's around, the player only gets half of a "MISS". In Game A, eggs will only fall from three of the henhouses instead of the four that are in Game B. As the game progresses, the rate of eggs and quantity will increase. In GAME A, the misses are reset every 100 caught eggs. In GAME B, the misses are only reset at multiples of 500.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Mickey Mouse

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Egg is the sixth game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series.

This G&W is strictly speaking, identical to the Game & Watch Wide Screen: Mickey Mouse, with the only variation between the two is the use of other characters. Mickey is replaced by an evil wolf with a large hat, wheras Minnie has made way for a hen shouting at the beast. This game has never been released in Japan (and other Asian countries) and is considered the first G&W designed exclusively for the Western market, due to publication rights of the Mickey Mouse character in the above mentioned game being prohibited by Disney for Japan use only.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Egg

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Fire is the seventh game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series.

This G&W game is considered the first remake of a previously released G&W model. The core of this version of "Fire" is still the same, but with new colored backgrounds and more developed animations. This time characters can also jump from the second floor (Game B), instead of just the third as in Game A. Also the pace of the game, as well as the scoring system, are totally different from the original version from the "Silver Series". Now the player earns a point each time a survivor bounces on the stretcher and not just when he reaches the ambulance.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Fire

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Turtle Bridge is the eight game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series.

In this G&W game the player has to guide an adventurer, with no boat nor swimming skills, back and forth between two islands to transport various goods with help of a colleague. In order to traverse, the player has to jump from one turtle shell to another, as they are aligned on the surface creating a sort of bridge. The turtles, from time to time submerge to eat a fish passing by. To avoid drowning, the player has to time his crossing with the fishes movements under water to evaluate when a turtle will disappear. In Game A, a single turtle, middle one, will not submerge and stays on top of the water. In Game B all turtles will dive.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Turtle Bridge

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Fire Attack is the ninth game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series.

The scenery takes place in the wild west as a cowboy has to defend his wooden fort from Native American Indians attacking it with fire sticks (top row) and matches (bottom row). The button layout is modified to represent each defending / attacking position. The attacks can take place from three positions in Game A upwards to four in Game B.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Fire Attack

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Snoopy Tennis is the tenth game in the third series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Wide Screen Series.

In this G&W, you play as Snoopy trying to play tennis with Charlie Brown. Sometimes Lucy will join in to complicate things a little bit. Contrary to most G&W games where the player has to move a character horizontally, this game has you moving Snoopy vertically up and down on three levels of a tree. Smashing the ball back is a possibility with the "hit" button featuring on the left side of the game.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Snoopy Tennis

description:
Mario Bros. is an LCD game with Mario and Luigi working in a bottling factory. It is a dual screen game and it's part of the Game & Watch series.

The player must move Mario and Luigi up and down so that they catch the cases moving on the conveyor belts. Move eight cases all the way up and onto a truck to go to the next level. When the trucks is almost full the driver impatiently appears from the truck window. When the truck is fully loaded it drives away, leaving a trail of dust. Mario and Luigi get a moment of rest, before the next truck appears and the boss tells them to get back to work. When a case is dropped it crashes and the Mario or Luigi is told off by their boss.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting the device shows all LCD segments

title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Mario Bros.

description:
Sea Ranger is an LCD game with two difficulty settings, with a built in alarm clock function.

The player must move a guy in a lifeboat from left to right to reach a big ship, while avoiding coconuts, boats, sharks and birds. A man in the ship on the right throws lifesavers down to the player, grab the lifesaver to climb aboard and score points, then try to rescue the next lifeboat guy and so on. When the player is hit by any of the hazards, the lifeboat flips over throwing the guy in the water and the player loses one life.

sample_screenshots.caption: When not playing it displays the time

title: Sea Ranger

description:
Tom's Adventure is an LCD handheld game with a built in alarm clock.

The player must move Tom from left to right to collect a treasure chest, while avoiding robbers, falling rocks and a dragon. Grab the chest and carry it back to the start while avoiding two robbers who will steal the treasure from you. Throw the chest through an opening and closing gatedoor to score points. Then grab the next chest and so on. The game plays a short melody when starting the game, and another melody at game over.
title: Tom's Adventure

description:
Highway is an LCD game with two difficulty settings and a built in alarm clock.

The player controls a car, moving left and right while driving on an endless road, picking up hitchhikers while avoiding obstacles. There are three lanes of obstacles which are dogs, signposts and tree trunks. Every once in a while a hitchhiker appears on the left side of the road, move all the way to the left lane pick up the girl and then try to drop her off at a sign on the right side of the screen. After three drop offs there is a gas bonus game, press any button to stop the constantly changing gas numbers, get three equal numbers to score points. The bonus game ends when the digits do not match up. After each gas bonus game the driving game continues at a slightly faster pace. Do not crash into objects, after three crashes the game is over.

sample_screenshots.caption: When not playing, it displays the time
Crashed into a dog on Game 2 difficulty
Game over while playing on Game 1 difficulty

title: Highway

description:
MG-04: Merry Cook is a Soviet clone of Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Chef .

The player controls a chef juggling around the food so that nothing touches the floor. If something does touches the floor, a mouse will pick it up and counts as a miss. Three misses will count as a game over. At irregular intervals a cat in the upper left corner will suspend a certain food item, making it harder for the player to guess which piece is flippable. Game B will have the player juggle four items, instead of the three in Game A.

The handheld has a built-in clock and alarm.
title: MG-04: Merry Cook

description:
In this dedicated LCD handheld game, Nelson's kidnapped Maggie and only Bartman can save her! In the first level Bart tries to collect Bartman's cape, mask and skateboard while dodging walnuts Nelson shoots at him with a slingshot. Being hit with a walnut costs a life.

After collecting all three items Bart transforms into Bartman and the second level begins. Bartman skates down the road after a fruit truck Nelson has jumped into. Nelson flings apples and watermelons, trying to knock Bartman off his skateboard. Every so often Santa's Little Helper will appear and give Bartman an apple that he can throw at Nelson when Nelson tries to hit him with a watermelon. Being hit with either an apple or watermelon costs a life.

After hitting Nelson with ten apples he's defeated and the game loops back to the first level, but projectiles move faster with each victory. The game continues until the player runs out of lives.
title: Bartman: Avenger of Evil

description:
Electronika IM-23: Avtoslalom (literally: Car Slalom) is an LCD handheld game produced in Soviet Union. The player controls a racing car that moves along one of three lanes. The player needs to press left or right keys to avoid obstacles. Each successfully passed obstacle adds one point to the score. If the car collides with an obstacle the player looses one of three lives. Lives are replenished at each 200, 500 and 1000 points. The game is played until all lives are lost or until the player accumulates 2999 points. There are 16 selectable speed settings and two game modes - A and B. In mode B there are considerably more obstacles on the track.

The handheld has a built in clock and alarm.
title: Elektronika IM-23: Avtoslalom

description:
Nu, pogodi! is the Soviet clone of Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Egg. This handheld features characters (wolf and hare) from popular Soviet animated show of the same name.

The player controls the wolf who needs to catch eggs sliding down conveyor belts from four directions. Each egg gives one point. If the wolf misses an egg it breaks and the player looses one of three lives. If an egg breaks when the hare is visible in the corner of the screen (the hare replaces the hen from the original game) the player only looses a half of life.There are two difficulty settings - game A and B.

The handheld has built-in clock and alarm.
title: Nu, pogodi!

description:
Elektronika 24-01. Igra na ekrane: Mickey Mouse (literally: Game on Screen: Mickey Mouse) is the Soviet clone of Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Mickey Mouse.

The player controls Mickey who needs to catch eggs sliding down conveyor belts from four directions. Each egg gives one point. If Mickey misses an egg it breaks and the player looses one of three lives. If an egg breaks when Minnie is visible in the corner of the screen the player only looses a half of life.There are two difficulty settings - game 1 and 2.

The handheld has built-in clock and alarm.
title: Elektronika 24-01. Igra na ekrane: Mickey Mouse

description:
Handheld containing 30 8-Bit Sega Master System & Sega Game Gear games.

  • Alex Kidd: High-Tech World
  • Alex Kidd in Miracle World
  • Alex Kidd: The Lost Stars
  • Assault City
  • Astro Warrior
  • Aztec Adventure
