title: Arcade Gamer Portable

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Green House is the fourth game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles.

You play as the gardener Stanley the Bugman defending his greenhouse from various parasites. You have to kill the numerous spiders and caterpillars/worms approaching your flowers, by pressing the "spray" button to use your insecticide. The spiders attack from above whilst the caterpillars/worms attack from below. When three flowers are eaten, the game will end.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Green House

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Donkey Kong is the second game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles.

As an indirect port of the arcade game, there are some slight differences in appearances, but the main goal of the game is still the same, helping the player release the captured girl from the clutches of Donkey Kong by unlocking the four locks holding the platform where the gorilla stands. This G&W is the first of it's kind to feature a directional pad.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Donkey Kong

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Mickey & Donald is the third game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles.

You'l control both Mickey and Donald acting as firefighters, subduing a six story building fire. Mickey can go up and down to fix various leaks in the hose, whilst Donald can be moved left and right to subdue the flames. All has to be done, while making sure Goofy doesn't fall asleep. When the flames are finally out, Minnie pops in to give Mickey some hugs and kisses. On the other hand, if the flames reach the top of the building then Donald's tail will burst into flame!
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Mickey & Donald

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Rain Shower is the seventh game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles.

You play as a character trying to dry his laundry out in his yard. One has to constantly go back and forth between the two floors of your house and pull one of the four strings from left to right to prevent the water to fall on your clothes. Every 100 points the sun will come back and give you a few seconds of peace. Game B will add crows which will sometimes pull the strings the opposite way.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Rain Shower

description:
Elektronika IM-03: Tajny okeana (literally: Mysteries of the Ocean) is a Soviet clone of Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Octopus.

The player needs to guide three explorers equipped with scuba gear pass a waiting octopus to get a hold of the sacks of gold hidden in a shipwreck. The player has to get as much gold as he can without getting touched by the giant squid. If the latter touches the character he's immediately captured by it. The game has two difficulty settings: Game A and B.

The handheld has a built in-clock and alarm.
title: Elektronika IM-03: Tajny okeana

description:
MG-09: Space Bridge is a Soviet clone of Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Fire.

The gameplay is identical to Game & Watch Wide Screen: Fire, but the setting is different. The game takes place on a remote planet where the astronauts are separated from their transport by three streams of lava. The astronauts jump from their base and the player controls the bridge which helps them get to the transport. The bridge is moved in three positions by pressing Left and Right keys. There are two difficulty settings: Game A and B. In game B the astronauts jump from the first and the second storeys of the base.

The handheld has a built-in clock and alarm.
title: MG-09: Space Bridge

description:
Electronika IM-10: Hockey is another Soviet clone of Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Egg with different setting. The player controls the goaltender who needs to catch pucks shot at him by hockey players from four corners. There are two difficulty settings.

The handheld has a built-in clock and alarm.
title: Elektronika IM-10: Hockey

description:
MG-13: Explorers of Space is another Soviet clone of Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Egg with space setting. A landed spaceship is attacked by enemy ships from four directions. The player must move the shield accordingly to deflect the missiles. There are two difficulty settings.

The handheld has built-in clock and alarm.
title: MG-13: Explorers of Space

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Oil Panic is the first game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles.

You play as character on the upper screen needing to collect and catch droplets of oil coming from a pipe on the ceiling with your bucket. When filled with three drops of oil, you'll need to rush towards the balcony to pass over the liquid to the randomly moving second character on the lower floor. One has to be careful on keeping an eye towards the second character, since missing his actions might result in covering innocent gas station customers in oil. Game A and B are practically identical, although game B ups the ante by faster movements and irregular action of the second characters and infrequent customers.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Oil Panic

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Donkey Kong II is the fifth game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles.

Essentially a port from Donkey Kong Jr. the arcade game, released one year earlier, this G&W title got the number II at the end of its title instead of "Jr.", to make it feel more like a true "sequel". You play as Junior, Donkey Kong's son, who has to go through the two screens to catch four keys in order to rescue his father. Since Junior can only use one key at a time, he needs to go through the various electric lines, vines and chains, while jumping over traps along the way multiple times. The only difference between Game A and B is that in Game B, enemies on the upper screen don't disappear when you open a lock, making things harder for Junior.

sample_screenshots.caption: At the top screen, preparing to grab the key
The first lock is opened. Working my way back up from the bottom screen

title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Donkey Kong II

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Life Boat is the eight game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles. Unreleased in Japan. Originally to be named Titanic, hence the codename TC-58.

This G&W game uses the concept of rescuing passengers jumping from the deck of a ship, by trying to land them in two lifeboats attached to a string, being pulled by two men. Each of the previously mentioned lifeboats can only contain four passengers at a time!. Once that number is reached, passengers will only be welcomed in the sea by sharks. Unloading the lifeboats to save the passengers from this fate is mandatory. Game B ups the ante by deploying only one lifeboat instead of the two in Game B. The pace and frequency of the passengers will increase accordingly.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Life Boat

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Pinball is the ninth game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles.

Essentially a arcade pinball machine on a multi LCD screen, the game incorporates rails, bumpers, targets, trapdoors and even some multi-ball bonuses (up to three balls at the time). Both screens include a pair of flippers. In Game A you only have three balls to reach the highest score possible. In Game B, you may only get one ball, but you'll be allowed to get some extras as your score goes higher and higher.

The "main character" of this G&W game, the ball itself, can move between numerous spots over the two screens, the most ever of any of the Game & Watch games available.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Pinball

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Black Jack is the tenth game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles. Black Jack is the last Multi Screen G&W game to be released and published in Japan.

Like the original card game, Black Jack is about reaching a number as close to 21 as possible with the cards that are given to you. If your adversary is closer to 21 than you, or if you go over 21, then you lose. The upper screen features your opponent's cards, while the lower one features yours. At the beginning of each game you are given 500 to bet, with 100 per turn.

Game B, instead of offering a variation of Game A's Black Jack, offers a slot machine simulator. One will see numbers from 3 to 7 rapidly changing on the lower screen. The goal is to press the "Bet" button at the right time to get the machine to stop on the same number for all 5 cards (the combination of all sevens being the best outcome)
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Black Jack

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Squish is the eleventh game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles. Unreleased in Japan.

Squish is a G&W game similar to Devil World. The upper screen features the character Grumpy manipulating a total of four buttons. These move the walls in the desired direction. You play as Ziggy, trapped in the bottom screen, with the goal to control him and to make sure he doesn't get squashed between two walls. Game B slightly differs from the concept in Game A, as an addition you'll have to try to capture four "Maze Bugs", each located in a corner of a room.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Squish

description:
Super Game Pod! is a non-screen handheld aimed at younger audience which features six mini-games which require some thinking and pressing the right button to proceed to next question and earn sound of success. Just like a handheld, the device contains left and right button, while in place of the screen there are various buttons for various games. Buttons marked with numbers from 1-10 and shapes are used for memory-related games. On the right side are rock-paper-scissors buttons and at the bottom are six buttons which launch selected mini-game.

Pressing the game buttons without starting a mini-game will just yield in a female voice telling you which buttons you have pressed. Otherwise, that same female voice is used in all the mini-games to tell you what to do and do not.

Six included mini-games are:

Migi, Hidari

The simplest game which tell you to press or not to press left and/or right button. By hearing "press right button" or "do not press left button" the player has to press the corresponding button or remain idle until next request. Only left and right buttons are used for this mini-game.

Kazu no Yaritori

The voice lists several different objects (i.e. tomatoes and apples) and the player must answer the total sum of them. Buttons labeled from 1-10 are used for this mini-game.

Ichi no Kioku

This is a memory card game. On the buttons from 1 to 10 are five pairs randomly assigned. Pressing button will tell you what is placed there. For example, pressing number 5 may tell you there's a apple there, and pressing 8 may hold an orange. Connecting all the pairs results in a success.

Suuji no Kioku

This game requires you to remember the right sequence of numbers. At first you have to press 3 numbers you hear in the right order, then 4, and so on. Missing to press the right number in the sequence will repeat the same sequence until you get it right.

Katachi no Hayaoshi

This mini-game uses same ten button which have number and various shapes on them. It requires the player to quickly press all the shapes that match the given condition. For example, if the voice says "press all the shapes that are not round", then pressing stars, rectangles and triangles would be satisfactory.

Otodashi Janken

A slightly irregular game of rock-paper-scissors where the goal isn't always to beat the given selection. Based on the request, the player will have to select rock, paper or scissors to either win or loose if that is required.
title: Super Game Pod!

description:
Elektronika IM-16: Okhota (literally: Fowling) is another Soviet variant of the original Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Egg. This time the player controls a hunter who shoots wild fowl flying from four directions. If the player misses three times it's Game Over. There are two difficulty settings.

The handheld has built-in clock and alarm.
title: Elektronika IM-16: Okhota

description:
Elektronika IM-19: Biathlon is a Soviet LCD handheld game created on the basic principle of Nintendo's Game & Watch Wide Screen: Egg, but there are some differences. There are four horizontal lanes on the playfield and the figures of biathlonists move along these lanes. When the figure reaches the end of the lane a target appears. The player needs to press one of four directional buttons in time with this to hit the target. The game ends after 3 misses. There are two difficulty settings.

The handheld has built-in clock and alarm.
title: Elektronika IM-19: Biathlon

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Bomb Sweeper is the twelfth game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles. Unreleased in Japan.

A bandit named Dynamite Jack placed explosives throughout the sewers and you, John Solver, have to defuse them all. Game A features 11 predetermined levels (the last being a huge maze with its own scrolling, similar to Squish) whereas Game B will bring you 15 random generated levels. The player needs to find his way by pushing certain walls blocking his path, to reach the bomb before the end of the countdown. More bombs are placed as the game progresses further through the levels.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Bomb Sweeper

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Safebuster is the thirteenth game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles. Unreleased in Japan. Before release Safe Buster was supposed to take place in a prison, hence the code name JB-63 (Jail Breaker).

You play as a guard trying to stop Willy Bomber, a bandit throwing explosives from the roof of a bank, trying to bust its safe. With a very large tube, you'll have to intercept the bombs and dump them on the side of the screen with a maximum of three bombs at the time. This G&W game show much similarities in collecting/dumping access materials just like Oil Panic. The more explosives you unload on the left, then the greater your chance to make the torch (on the left part of the screen) bounce to the upper screen, therefore reaching Willy's crate of bombs, resulting in a massive explosion. Game B adds the difficulty the appearance of a cover at irregular intervals on the left side of the screen, preventing you from unloading the bombs for a few seconds
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Safebuster

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Gold Cliff is the fourteenth game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles. Unreleased in Japan.

You play as an archaeologist on his way to many expeditions. In order to reach the treasures, you'll need to avoid the enemies as well as precisely jump on the many disappearing platforms, whilst not forgetting the key to unlock the door on the upper levels. After a few levels the explorer faces the guardian of the temple which must be defeated to progress further. Gold Cliff is composed of 24 worlds and 144 different levels and is the first G&W game to feature a "continue" option.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Gold Cliff

description:
Game & Watch Multi Screen: Zelda is the fifteenth and last game in the fourth (and biggest) series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Multi Screen Series, consisting of 15 titles. Unreleased in Japan.

The G&W Zelda game mixes the exploration part of the first Zelda game with the combat gameplay of Zelda II. The goal of your quest is to save Princess Zelda by gathering pieces of the Triforce, each hidden in one of the eight dungeons of the Hyrule Kingdom. Each dungeon is crowded with monsters and ghosts. To go from one room to the next you'll have to choose between two paths, but only after defeating an armed Goblin. When defeated you'll get an randomized item: the dungeon map, extra hearts, an axe or magic potions. After defeating the dragon in the last room the piece of Triforce is awarded to Link.

The upper screen shows all the useful information: the items you own, the dungeon map, pieces of Triforce gathered and the boss location. The lower screen shows all the action that is happening.
title: Game & Watch Multi Screen: Zelda

description: My Pet is a Tamagotchi clone. The player's task is taking care of a virtual pet, by satisfying his needs in terms of eating, playing, cleaning, healing and resting. The game starts from hatching an egg and my take up to 20 years of animal age. Food menu is divided into feeding, water and appetizers. Play menu features listening music, paper/stone/scissors game and dancing. Progress in the game depicts the age, weight and well-being of the animal (9 levels).
title: My Pet

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Mario's Cement Factory is the second game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the (New) Wide Screen Series, consisting of 8 titles. More colorful and child-friendly, the models from the New Wide Screen series (still described as Wide Screen on the boxes) aren't much different from the previous line of G&W games, save for a cheaper price and a different shell design.

The player controls Mario working in a cement factory, where one has to make sure the cement carried from the top of the screen reaches one of the two concrete mixers on the lower corners of the screen safely. The cement can't go directly into the mixers though. It must first go through four tanks which Mario can open by activating levers. His task is to go back and forth between all four spots and release the concrete before anything is spilled. Failure to do so will result in dumping of said concrete on the truckers waiting to make their delivery. To reach the different levers Mario must travel between floors via elevators, which must be taken carefully to avoid Mario falling off. Apart from a higher difficulty in Game B, nothing chances between the two game models.

sample_screenshots.caption: Getting ready to transfer cement to the lower hopper
Hiding in the nook on the left. The hoppers on the right side are getting full

title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Mario's Cement Factory

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Donkey Kong Jr. is the first game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the (New) Wide Screen Series, consisting of 8 titles. More colorful and child-friendly, the models from the New Wide Screen series (still described as Wide Screen on the boxes) aren't much different from the previous line of G&W games, save for a cheaper price and a different shell design.

Donkey Kong Jr. is a semi-direct port from the Famicom game Donkey Kong Jr. and can be classified as the direct sequel to Donkey Kong 2 from the Multi Screen series. Mario who once again has come back to capture Donkey Kong and put him in a cage. The player controls Junior who has to set his father free. In order to succeed, one must control Junior by jumping and climbing vines and disarm traps by falling coconuts, whilst avoiding crows. The ultimate goal is to secure a key to open the lock on the cage. Game A and B only differ by the time Junior can stay hanging on a vine.

By pressing Game A and Game B simultaneously the best score will appear on the screen. This function will be featured in almost every G&W game from then on. This model is also the G&W game with the most buttons (10), including Alarm and ACL.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Donkey Kong Jr.

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Manhole is the third game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the (New) Wide Screen Series, consisting of 8 titles. More colorful and child-friendly, the models from the New Wide Screen series (still described as Wide Screen on the boxes) aren't much different from the previous line of G&W games, save for a cheaper price and a different shell design. Unpublished in Japan.

Manhole is essentially an upgraded version of the Game & Watch Gold: Manhole with enhanced graphics. The core of the game with his gameplay hasn't changed significantally, despite the purely graphical facelift. The screen is wider, the characters show more details and each fall leads to a new animation. The alarm woman ring from the Gold version has been replaced by a younger lady.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Manhole

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Tropical Fish is the fourth game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the (New) Wide Screen Series, consisting of 8 titles. More colorful and child-friendly, the models from the New Wide Screen series (still described as Wide Screen on the boxes) aren't much different from the previous line of G&W games, save for a cheaper price and a different shell design. Unpublished in Japan.

G&W Tropical Fish sees the player juggling exotic species of fish, living in your two fish tanks, who are constantly jumping, trying to escape their tanks. The concept of this game is similar to Game & Watch Silver: Fire where the ambulance and burning building are replaced by two fish tanks and the stretcher made way for a fish bowl. Your character can move to four different spots instead of three in Fire. The fishes themselves can also return to the fish tank they came from instead of just crossing over in Game B.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Tropical Fish

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Super Mario Bros. is the fifth game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the (New) Wide Screen Series, consisting of 8 titles. More colorful and child-friendly, the models from the New Wide Screen series (still described as Wide Screen on the boxes) aren't much different from the previous line of G&W games, save for a cheaper price and a different shell design. Unpublished in Japan.

The New Wide Screen Version of Super Mario Bros. was released approximately two years after the Crystal Screen version which, like the whole Crystal Series didn't sell well. The overall gameplay and mechanics remain similar, except the screen-size and clarity of the game itself.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Super Mario Bros.

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Climber is the sixth game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the (New) Wide Screen Series, consisting of 8 titles. More colorful and child-friendly, the models from the New Wide Screen series (still described as Wide Screen on the boxes) aren't much different from the previous line of G&W games, save for a cheaper price and a different shell design. Unpublished in Japan

The New Wide Screen Version of Climber was released approximately two years after the Crystal Screen version which, like the whole Crystal Series didn't sell well. The overall gameplay and mechanics remain similar, except the screen-size and clarity of the game itself.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Climber

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Balloon Fight is the seventh game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the (New) Wide Screen Series, consisting of 8 titles. More colorful and child-friendly, the models from the New Wide Screen series (still described as Wide Screen on the boxes) aren't much different from the previous line of G&W games, save for a cheaper price and a different shell design. Unpublished in Japan

The New Wide Screen Version of Balloon Fight was released approximately two years after the Crystal Screen version which, like the whole Crystal Series didn't sell well. The overall gameplay and mechanics remain similar, except the screen-size and clarity of the game itself. Released on the same day as the two bigger re-makes of the Crystal Series: Super Mario Bros. & Climber.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Balloon Fight

description:
Game & Watch Wide Screen: Mario the Juggler is the eight and final game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the (New) Wide Screen Series, consisting of 8 titles. More colorful and child-friendly, the models from the New Wide Screen series (still described as Wide Screen on the boxes) aren't much different from the previous line of G&W games, save for a cheaper price and a different shell design. Unpublished in Japan.

Mario the Juggler as a G&W game arrived at the very end of the G&W era, when the more advanced Game Boy Classic System is already out and the Super Famicom System makes it's debut on the Japanese market. Considered the last G&W game released.

The concept of the last G&W game is the same as the first G&W game, Ball. The anonymous character of the first game being replaced by Mario, juggling hearts, bombs and stars respectively. In Game B, you have to juggle four items instead of three and you'll get assistance from Lakitu and the Hammer Bros. The Mario theme is played before each game starts.
title: Game & Watch Wide Screen: Mario the Juggler

description: 3-D Escape!: 1000 Mazes has two ways to play: Maze and Adventure. The object of Maze is to escape out of a maze, and there are 1000 different ones to choose from (you enter the number of the maze you want to try). Adventure is the same, but you must first recover 3 artifacts from within the maze (hence the 'treasure quest'). Certain ranges of maze numbers have different sized maps (maze #'s 000-599 are on an 8x8 grid, 600-699 are on an 8x9 grid and so on).
title: 3-D Escape! 1000 Mazes

description: The Pokéwalker was a pedometer originally bundled with copies of with Pokémon HeartGold and SoulSilver. A Pokémon from one of those two games can be sent to the Pokéwalker, where it will gain experience points from the steps the player takes in the real world. A currency called watts also builds up as steps are taken, and can be used to purchase one-time use items that offer a chance to find an item or catch a wild Pokémon. Three items and three captured Pokémon can be stored on the device, and will be sent back to the Nintendo DS game the next time the Pokéwalker communicates with it. The Pokémon and items that can be found depend on the location selected when a Pokémon is sent from the Nintendo DS. Two courses are available at the start, and more can be unlocked by accumulating a certain number of watts, performing a specific task in HeartGold or SoulSilver, or receiving a special Wonder Card from an official event.
title: Pokéwalker

description: Pokémon Pikachu is a pedometer with a virtual pet element. Players are given a pet Pikachu, and must walk to build up a currency called watts. Once enough watts have been earned, the player may spend them on gifts that will increase Pikachu's happiness. If too much time goes by without giving Pikachu a gift, it will become less friendly towards the player. Watts may also be gambled in a slot machine minigame. The device contains a real-time clock, and Pikachu operates on a daily schedule that includes eating, bathing, and sleeping.
title: Pokémon Pikachu

description:
Pokémon Pikachu 2 GS is an updated version of the original Pokémon Pikachu pedometer and virtual pet. Players are given a pet Pikachu, and must walk to build up a currency called watts. Once enough watts have been earned, the player may give them to Pikachu to increase its happiness. Watts may also be earned from a guessing minigame. If the player does not walk at least 100 steps in a day, Pikachu will become less friendly towards the player. The device contains a real-time clock, and Pikachu operates on a daily schedule that includes eating, bathing, and sleeping.

The device has an infrared port, through which it can communicate with Pokémon Gold, Silver, and Crystal versions via their Mystery Gift feature. The player may choose a number of watts to send, which will turn into a rare item for the receiving game. Watts may also be sent to another Pokémon Pikachu 2 GS device.
title: Pokémon Pikachu 2 GS

description:
Game & Watch Table Top: Mario's Cement Factory is the second game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Table Top Series, also known as the Color Screen Table Top series, consisting of just 4 titles. Each of the four models Nintendo produced for this series was shaped like an coin-op arcade machine. Though not a handheld by name, it's considered a dedicated handheld by definition.

The Table Top version of Mario's Cement Factory came out a few months earlier than the Wide Screen version, the Table Top version has a bigger screen, enhanced color graphics and sound effects due to the color LCD (CLCD) model and larger housing.
title: Game & Watch Table Top: Mario's Cement Factory

description:
Game & Watch Table Top: Donkey Kong Jr. is the first game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Table Top Series, also known as the Color Screen Table Top series, consisting of just 4 titles. Each of the four models Nintendo produced for this series was shaped like an coin-op arcade machine. Though not a handheld by name, due to its large size, it's considered a dedicated handheld by definition.

The Table Top version of Donkey Kong Jr. has a bigger screen, enhanced color graphics and sound effects due to the color LCD (CLCD) model and larger housing, compared to its Wide Screen counterpart. Despite the similar name, the organization of the traps, level design and presence of helium balloons (which weren't part of the original version), alters the gameplay.
title: Game & Watch Table Top: Donkey Kong Jr.

description:
Game & Watch Table Top: Snoopy is the third game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Table Top Series, also known as the Color Screen Table Top series, consisting of just 4 titles. Each of the four models Nintendo produced for this series was shaped like an coin-op arcade machine. Though not a handheld by name, due to its large size, it's considered a dedicated handheld by definition.

The Table Top version of Snoopy has a bigger screen, enhanced color graphics and sound effects due to the color LCD (CLCD) model and larger housing. The player controls Snoopy, who has to prevent the musical notes from Schroeder's piano reaching the top level of the screen, where Woodstock is sleeping. The player controls Snoopy with his hammer, who has to jump from platform to platform to hit the floating music notes. In Game A one only has to deal with three music notes, whilst the pacing and the amount of music notes (four instead of three) to handle are increasing in Game B. After every 100 points Lucy, sleeping at the bottom will kick Schroeder's small piano.
title: Game & Watch Table Top: Snoopy

description:
Game & Watch Table Top: Popeye is the fourth and final game in the fifth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Table Top Series, also known as the Color Screen Table Top series, consisting of just 4 titles. Each of the four models Nintendo produced for this series was shaped like an coin-op arcade machine. Though not a handheld by name, due to its large size, it's considered a dedicated handheld by definition.

The Table Top version of Popeye has a bigger screen, enhanced color graphics and sound effects due to the color LCD (CLCD) model and larger housing. The player controls Popeye who has to fight off Bluto, who's trying to abduct Olive Oil. The ultimate goal is to punch Bluto off the side of the pier into the water. Hitting Bluto after a few successful times, he will retreat and eventually hit the water, but one must dodge his counterattacks, since this will send you back down the pier. On some occasions Olive Oil manages to temporarily untie her bonds and will send down a can of spinach to boost your strength. Defending and attacking moves are the only way to gain victory in this boxing match.
title: Game & Watch Table Top: Popeye

description:
Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Donkey Kong Jr. is the third game in the sixth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Panorama Screen Series. With it's tilt-able screen, this series managed to offer the same experience as the Table Top Series, but on a much more portable format and for a more affordable price. Of the six titles in the series, three were re-editions of previous Table Top Games.

Donkey Kong Jr. is one of the re-editions of the Table Top Versions which were released before. It's gameplay and it's general look hasn't changed in comparison with the other version, except for better sound quality and overall colors.
title: Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Donkey Kong Jr.

description:
Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Mickey Mouse is the fifth game in the sixth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Panorama Screen Series. With it's tilt-able screen, this series managed to offer the same experience as the Table Top Series, but on a much more portable format and for a more affordable price. Of the six titles in the series, three were re-editions of previous Table Top Games. Unpublished in Japan.

Mickey Mouse isn't one of the re-editions of the Table Top Versions which were released before, despite Mickey's appearance in some of the other G&W series games. Mickey Mouse can be seen as an alternate version of Donkey Kong Circus. Instead of controlling Donkey Kong, the player controls Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck is standing on the side instead of Mario. Compared to the mockery Mario displayed in Donkey Kong Circus, Donald isn't mocking Mickey. On the contrary, he jumps as if he was panicked and worried about Mickey's well-being. It's concept and gameplay are the same as Donkey Kong Circus

The product code of this game MK-95 and the sixth game in this series Donkey Kong Circus, codenamed MK-96, seemed to have their code names switched, since MK (= Mickey Mouse) and DC (= Donkey Kong Circus), but this isn't the case.
title: Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Mickey Mouse

description:
Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Mario's Bombs Away is the fourth game in the sixth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Panorama Screen Series. With it's tilt-able screen, this series managed to offer the same experience as the Table Top Series, but on a much more portable format and for a more affordable price. Of the six titles in the series, three were re-editions of previous Table Top Games.

Mario's Bombs Away isn't one of the re-editions of the Table Top Versions which were released before, but a new game in the G&W franchise. The player controls Mario transporting bombs from one side of the screen to the other. Whilst moving, enemies in the trees above try to light the fuse. To avoid the possible explosion, one must press the up/down button, allowing you to lower the bomb to hip level, dodging the ambush from above. The ground you traverse on is riddled with multiple oil puddles and carelessly thrown away cigarette ends from your comrades. As in Turtle Bridge the person collecting the bombs from Mario does so on a irregular basis.
title: Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Mario's Bombs Away

description:
Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Snoopy is the first game in the sixth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Panorama Screen Series. With it's tilt-able screen, this series managed to offer the same experience as the Table Top Series, but on a much more portable format and for a more affordable price. Of the six titles in the series, three were re-editions of previous Table Top Games.

Snoopy is one of the re-editions of the Table Top Versions which were released before. It's gameplay and it's general look hasn't changed in comparison with the other version, except Nintendo took full advantage of the sound capabilities of this G&W series. Each of the notes played by Schroeder sounds different, with the addition of the sounds Snoopy makes when hammering a note. Aside from the overall better sound quality, the notes played by Schroeder are in different colors to help the player to spot the difference between them.
title: Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Snoopy

description:
Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Popeye is the second game in the sixth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Panorama Screen Series. With it's tilt-able screen, this series managed to offer the same experience as the Table Top Series, but on a much more portable format and for a more affordable price. Of the six titles in the series, three were re-editions of previous Table Top Games. This version did have a release in Japan, whilst the rest of the world received both versions (both Table Top and Panorama Screen).

Popeye is one of the re-editions of the Table Top Versions which were released before. It's gameplay and it's general look hasn't changed in comparison with the other version, except a swordfish's presence in Game B aiming to hit you with his pointy nose.
title: Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Popeye

description:
Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Donkey Kong Circus is the sixth and final game in the sixth series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Panorama Screen Series. With it's tilt-able screen, this series managed to offer the same experience as the Table Top Series, but on a much more portable format and for a more affordable price. Of the six titles in the series, three were re-editions of previous Table Top Games. Unpublished in Japan.

Donkey Kong Circus isn't one of the re-editions of the Table Top Versions which were released before, despite Donkey Kong's appearance in some of the other G&W series games. Donkey Kong Circus can be seen as an enhanced version of Chef. The player control Donkey Kong balancing on a barrel in a warehouse, juggling pineapples. One has to move sideways to catch the fruit, whilst covering the whole width of the screen. One has to make sure not to touch the fireballs, that are falling alongside the pineapples. Mario, which is standing on the side, isn't helping Donkey Kong, but merely mocking him if he manages to catch a fireball instead and burning his hands.

The product code of this game MK-96 and the fifth game in this series Mickey Mouse, codenamed DC-95, seemed to have their code names switched, since MK (= Mickey Mouse) and DC (= Donkey Kong Circus), but this isn't the case.
title: Game & Watch Panorama Screen: Donkey Kong Circus

description: This game can either be played with a computer opponent or another player. The player on the offense side must get the ball in the basket (which is represented by a red dot surrounding the goal) and the computer or the person on the defense side will or must attempt to prevent the person on the offense side from getting the ball in.
title: Head to Head Basketball

description:
Game & Watch Super Color: Crab Grab is the second (and last) of only two released games in the seventh series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Super Color Screen Series. This series arrived near the end of the G&W lifespan in Japan, therefor weren't the success Nintendo expected. This series, in contrast to the previous, uses vertically (portrait) orientated screens instead of horizontal (landscape) screens. Despite the name, the Super Color G&W titles aren't using colored liquid crystals, but only use applied colored filters to simulate the presence thereof.
In this title, one plays as Mr. Grab who has to push back endless waves of Demon Crabs, progressively advancing towards the bottom of the screen. In order to proceed to the next level, you'll have to place yourself under a column of crabs and push them back up as fast as possible. The faster the column has been taken care of, the larger the amount of bonus points will be. If the crabs reach the bottom, you'll lose a life. The controls on the G&W are two simple buttons, one for each available thumb (Left/Right and Up/Down).
title: Game & Watch Super Color: Crab Grab

description:
Game & Watch Super Color: Spitball Sparky is the first of only two released games in the seventh series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Super Color Screen Series. This series arrived near the end of the G&W lifespan in Japan, therefor weren't the success Nintendo expected. This series, in contrast to the previous, uses vertically (portrait) orientated screens instead of horizontal (landscape) screens. Despite the name, the Super Color G&W titles aren't using colored liquid crystals, but only use applied colored filters to simulate the presence thereof.

Spitball Sparky 's gameplay is similar to the game Breakout, where the player controls Sparky, a small character with a trumpet shaped mouth, catching and spitting a ball capable of destroying the on-screen blocks. As one progresses further into the game, the walls start moving or increase their numbers. One can control the ball even before it reaches Sparky's mouth and apply a different force by adjusting the character's breath. In Game B, certain blocks blink and require two hits before they disappear.
title: Game & Watch Super Color: Spitball Sparky

description:
Game & Watch Micro Vs. System: Donkey Kong Hockey is the third (and last) of three released games in the eight series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Micro Vs. System Series. This series allowed for two players to battle against one another on the same screen. The Micro Vs. series boasted a wider screen and the innovative storage feature of the two small joy-pads and their wires inside the shell of the system.

Donkey Kong Hockey features an ice rink for a hockey game between Mario and Donkey Kong. Each character has to try to throw as many hockey pucks as possible in his opponent's goal, whilst staying on his own side. Though limited, the movement of the player allows you to change the speed of the pucks. The first to score ten times is declared winner. In some cases the referee blocks the pucks or mysterious "Crazy Spots" appear on the rink, modifying the trajectories. Game A has you play against the CPU, whilst Game B gives two players the opportunity to take part in a battle against each other.
title: Game & Watch Micro Vs. System: Donkey Kong Hockey

description:
Game & Watch Micro Vs. System: Donkey Kong 3 is the second of three released games in the eight series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Micro Vs. System Series. This series allowed for two players to battle against one another on the same screen. The Micro Vs. series boasted a wider screen and the innovative storage feature of the two small joy-pads and their wires inside the shell of the system.

Donkey Kong 3 sees the returns of Stanley, the young gardener, who killed insects in the G&W game Green House in what is essentially the direct sequel to that game. Stanley (on the right side of the screen) has to face Donkey Kong (on the left side of the screen) by using insecticide to force parasites on the opposite way. When the insects reach one of the two character's garden, then points are scored by the opponent end a "miss" is given to the unlucky one. The amount of gas loaded in once's device is limited, so when the gauge reaches empty, you'll have to refuel your spray with the drops coming from the corners of the screen. In order to balance the game it's possible to increase the rate of falling drops to refuel your insecticide. Game A sees you battling against a CPU, whilst Game B sees you battling a human player.
title: Game & Watch Micro Vs. System: Donkey Kong 3

alternate_titles.title: Game & Watch Micro Vs. System: Boxing

description:
Game & Watch Micro Vs. System: Boxing is the first of three released games in the eight series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Micro Vs. System Series. This series allowed for two players to battle against one another on the same screen. The Micro Vs. series boasted a wider screen and the innovative storage feature of the two small joy-pads and their wires inside the shell of the system. The US version of the Micro Vs. Boxing game was renamed to Punch-Out!! using the popularity of the eponymous arcade version.

Players will have to fight during nine rounds of 1 minute each, to claim victory. The up and down directions are used to set the height of your strike or blocking stances, whereas the rest of the D-pad will allow you to move around the ring. A point system, like an energy meter, will give you real time information about the health and shape of your boxer. In order to balance fights between two players with different skill levels, it's possible to set each fighter's amount of energy beforehand.
title: Game & Watch Micro Vs. System: Punch-Out!!

description:
Game & Watch Crystal Screen: Super Mario Bros. is the first of only three released games in the eight series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Crystal Screen Series. This series consist of games previously released in the (New) Wide Screen Series, but with ergonomic features and new transparent screens. Unpublished in Japan.

One plays as Mario on a rescue mission to save Princess Toadstool (Peach), through side-scrolling levels, battling familiar enemies (Lakitu, Bullet Bills, Koopa Troopas). Each of the eight worlds are designed to to be distinctively different from each other and each level holds a different challenge to complete. Such challenges are covering a certain distance, finishing a challenge within a specific time limit, finding the exit of a maze. Once the eight levels (task) of a world are taken care off, you'll receive a kiss from the princess and move on to the next level. There are 72 levels in total compared to the 32 in the Wide Screen version.
title: Game & Watch Crystal Screen: Super Mario Bros.

description:
Game & Watch Crystal Screen: Climber. is the second of only three released games in the eight series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Crystal Screen Series. This series consist of games previously released in the (New) Wide Screen Series, but with ergonomic features and new transparent screens. Unpublished in Japan.

One plays as a character, named Climber, who has to reach the 25 summits in the game. Blocks will appear and stop the progress, but these can be destroyed by a few jumps. If one gets stuck on a single platform a second character, Blockman, arrives. If he touches your character one will loose a life, if he first touches a hole, previously made by you or a natural one, he'll automatically turns into a platform, therefore allowing you to progress. With the help of the mystical bird Hatori and progressing through the levels one encounters a boss, on a 5 level interval, which you have to beat with a sword. Besides the tactical aspect of creating and destroying platforms, one has to take into account moving platforms and thorn plants blocking your way. Some versions of the game Climber were sold with a small illustrated plastic pouch, when applied to the G&W game ended up creating a mountain background for the game.
title: Game & Watch Crystal Screen: Climber

description:
Game & Watch Crystal Screen: Balloon Fight is the third (and final) of only three released games in the eight series of Game & Watch games published by Nintendo, also known as the Crystal Screen Series. This series consist of games previously released in the (New) Wide Screen Series, but with ergonomic features and new transparent screens. Unpublished in Japan.

The final goal is to help the Balloon Man reach a map showing his worst enemy's location. The map has been shredded to pieces and attached to balloons spread across the levels. One has to use your jet pack to collect as many pieces as possible, whilst avoiding sparks. These will have you fall into the seas below when touched. The "Eject" button controls the altitude of the jet pack. The more you push it, the higher you will go. Whereas, if you don't push it at all, your character will be sent into a free fall. Bonus stages are added, allowing you to grab extra balloons during a short period of time. Rocks in the water grant you a temporarily minute of rest. Every 8 levels a boss encounter ensues, where you have to dodge and defeat the enemy. Over 200 levels are available, which can be completed by collecting 25 balloons. The "Game Over" screen system, after 3 lives lost, isn't present anymore. One can continue indefinitely as long as you score at least 100 points between two failures. Some versions of the game Balloon Fight were sold with a small illustrated plastic pouch, when applied to the G&W game ended up creating a mountain background for the game.
title: Game & Watch Crystal Screen: Balloon Fight

description:
The Tetris MicroCard is an officially licensed dedicated handheld. The system is powered by an ATmega 328P and has a 1-bit 128x64 OLED display. The system has a directional pad and two face buttons similar to Nintendo's Game Boy, as well as two switches on the top for power and sound. It's powered by a small 180mAh battery which can be recharged using a standard Micro-USB connector on the bottom of the device.

The game is a simple but fully-featured rendition of Tetris based on the official Tetris guidelines. The d-pad is used to move your Tetrimino to the left and right, as well as perform a soft drop or a hard drop. The two face buttons are used to rotate your Tetrimino clockwise or counterclockwise. The game has a total of fifteen levels of difficulty which like other version of the game simply increase the speed at-which the Tetrimos fall as you clear lines.
title: Tetris MicroCard

description: Auto Race is a handheld racing game made from re-purposed calculator hardware. The player controls a car which can be positioned in one of three lanes and can increase speed by shifting between four gears. The player must beat the clock and avoid collisions with other cars, which are displayed by dashes on the display.
title: Auto Race

description:
The Neo Geo Mini is a dedicated handheld console in the style of a Neo Geo MVS arcade cabinet with 40 pre-installed games. The system features a built-in 3.5 inch 4:3 LCD screen. It has four main action buttons, start & select buttons, and a arcade joystick style analog stick. On the left & right sides of the device are a pair of USB-C ports used for connecting up Neo Geo CD style gamepads (sold separately). On the back of the device is the power button, a Mini-HDMI output, 3.5mm audio output, and a third USB-C port for the external power.

The games included with the system are:

  • 3 Count Bout (International only)
  • Aggressors of Dark Kombat (Japan only)

description: Football is a handheld American football game for two players. The player has six buttons at his or her disposal, three to control the movement of the current player (forward, and to either side of the field), a status, score and kick button. The game plays in hot-seat and the player who is on offense currently plays while the computer defends. The game lasts 10 minutes, but the clock is paused between quarters.
title: Football

description: Missile attack, later rebranded as Battlestar Galactica: Space Alert is a dedicated handheld action game in which the player must fight incoming missiles (Cylon Raiders in the re-release). To win the player must intercept 20 of them. The player can move to three positions and fire counter missiles (laser torpedoes in the re-release). In practice it comes down that red dots will come down the playfield and the player must move his or her red dot in its path and press the fire button which launches another red dot upwards. If it hits the enemy is intercepted.
title: Missile Attack

description: Comp IV is a dedicated handheld game which plays a digital version of Cows and Moos, better known as Mastermind. The computer thinks of a code and the player must guess it. After each guess the computer will light numbers on the device indicating the amount of correct numbers and number in the correct position.
title: Comp IV

description: This version of the Tamagotchi virtual pet tasks players with caring for the Pokémon Eevee. The creature needs to be fed and groomed, and will occasionally leave hairballs for the player to clean up. Two different minigames exist to help keep Eevee happy. Depending on how the player has cared for Eevee, it may become one of its eight evolutions, or turn into one of three special Eevee variants. Unlike other Tamagotchi variants, Eevee cannot die. Instead, if its owner is neglectful, it will say goodbye and force them to start over.
title: Eevee × Tamagotchi

description:
Data Zapper: Model M7000 is a hand held personal data assistant type of device for holding names, phone numbers etc. It can also be used to draw faces and contains both a single player game and a two player game; Tetris: A version of the original 1987 Tetris* by Elorg, licensed to Bullet-Proof Software and sub-licensed to Mani Technology. This game is played in portrait mode.

  • Sea Battle: This is a two player game based on Battleship, two players compete using an infra-red link to connect their Data Zappers, this game is played in landscape mode.

Both games are played using a combination of the four direction buttons plus additional keys.

The device opens like a book and the top cover can be folded right round so that it lies flush against the back. Basic instructions are printed inside the lid, on the right hand side is a wheel to adjust the contrast.

The device is unusual in that it has two battery compartments, the main compartment which holds two AAA batteries and a backup compartment which holds a CR2002 battery. There is no mains power option.

It weighs 137 g without batteries and measures approx 14 cm x 10 cm x 1.5 cm.
title: Data Zapper: Model M7000

description:
The Lexibook Electronic Thesaurus: Model DC 750 is a small handheld dictionary with thesaurus, synonym, grammar, homophone, conjugation and inflection functions. It also has a crossword helper function, anagram solver and a games mode.

The display is nineteen character wide black-on-grey in a dot-matrix style with each character being seven dots high and five dots wide. When the device needs to display lengthy text it scrolls across the display right to left.

Games mode is selected by pressing the yellow button that looks like the five on a dice, one of four such buttons situated above the QWERTY keyboard, the games button is the second from the right. The games available are:

  • Hangman: the game starts by letting the player select the number of characters in the word to be found, the shortest length is three characters and the longest is thirteen. The game then displays the word as a series of question marks, e.g. ??????. The player presses letters and the game either places the letter into the word or it responds with a message such as 'There is no P'. The player has nine attempts to guess the word before it's Game Over.
  • Jumble: Once again the player sets the word length but this time the game provides a jumbled word such as BBYUGR for GRUBBY and the player's task is to enter the correct, unscrambled word.
  • Word Search: After selecting a word length a word is displayed together with a number. The number shows how many words of three or more letters can be made from the original source word, it is the player's task to enter them all and as each word is entered and accepted the displayed number decreases.

The device weighs just over 50 g without its CR2032 battery and measures approximately 9.5cm x 6cm x 1.25cm.
title: Lexibook Electronic Thesaurus: Model DC 750

description:
Tails' Skypatrol is a simple handheld game that was included in McDonalds' Happy Meals.

The game comes in a small plastic case with an embossed the principle character. The game is played on a small LCD screen measuring 2cm by 1.5cm which has a fixed cloudscape background. This is a side scrolling game in which the player controls Tails who appears on the right of the screen. A series of rings scroll in from left to right and the player's task is to collect them by moving Tails up/down by means of the two buttons to the right of the screen. Collecting thirty rings completes the level, the next level will be exactly the same but faster, missing ten rings means Game Over.

The game has sound, a regular bleep which increases when the game sped picks up, and short tunes for game over and end of level.

The game has an irregular shape but measures approx 7.5cm wide, 6cm top to bottom and 1.5cm deep. There are two buttons on the front for up/down movement, and an on/off switch at the back. It is powered by a single L736H button battery which is held securely in a cage from which it cannot be removed..
title: Tails' Skypatrol

description: Catch fishes as they jump out of the water. But stay away from the shark. The difference between the two modes (A or B) is the number of fishes jumping out of the water at the same time. Two fishes in mode A. Three fishes in mode B.
title: Fishing

description:
Mixberry MGC 105 is a dedicated handheld console. It has D-pad, "A" and "B" buttons, USB input, "Start" and "Reset" triggers, a AV video and mono audio output. On the back side is a battery compartment for 3 1.5V Size AAA batteries.

The system contains 60 built-in games. The included games are: A Day A Painting Adjusting Pictures Air Fire Badminton Baseball Basketball Beat Shrew Mouse Black White Chess Bowling Chicken Village Clear Store Collecting Gold Crossing The River Diamond Drop Earth Fighter Eat Bean Explosion Falcon Fight To Fire Fighter Find Same Picture Fireplan Firewar Fishing Fixing Walls Flash Ghost Fly Ball Fly Dragonfly Fly War Football Fruit Dimishing Goal Guess Fruit Hua Rong Road Incept Presents Jigsaw Knocking Brick Magic Line Mark's Track Matching Pictures Maze Memorizing Cards Memory Mind Bender Ping Pong Precious Stone Push The Boxes Raecal Rally Ranning Sea Fishing Shooting Shuttle Silent Water Sliding Blocks Snake Space War Strong Builder Tennis Warehouse
title: Mixberry MGC 105

description:
Mathemagician is an educational calculator which includes six games. Each game has a different overlay for the screen and can be played with one or two players.

  • Number Machine - A very basic number learning game. A number is shown on the display and the child must match it on the keypad.
  • Countin' On - The game gives a sequence of numbers and the player must fill in the next number when the sequence stops.
  • Walk the Plank - Deduce the hidden number in three tries, after each try you hear if it's higher or lower.
  • Football - Solve arithmetic to make plays and advance yards on the football field.
  • Lunar Lander - Try to land a lander safely from 300ft. Numbers on the screen indicate fuel, speed and distance to surface. Only playable for one player.
  • Gooey Gumdrop - Find the secret location.

Aside from the six games there is also a training mode for general arithmetic.
title: Mathemagician

alternate_titles.title: Merlin: The Original Electronic Wizard Game

description:
Merlin: The Electronic Wizard is a dedicated handheld game with a display consisting of 11 LEDs. The LEDs also function as buttons. The device plays six different games:

  • Tic Tac Toe - The classic game of get three in a row.
  • Music Machine - Not an actual game, but a digital sequencer/synthesizer.
  • Echo - A game similar to Simon Says.
  • Blackjack 13 - A variant of Blackjack where the player needs to get close to 13 instead of 21.
  • Magic Square - A variant of Lights Out.
  • Mindbender - A variant of Mastermind.

The 2004 re-release features digitized speech.
title: Merlin: The Electronic Wizard

description: Goal Keeper is an LCD handheld console the gameplay of which is quite simple: keep the balls out of the goal. Balls come from two directions, left or right, and Game B is faster than Game A.
title: Tronica GK 10: Goal Keeper

description:
Battle Zone is a simple trench warfare shooting game.

You can first select one of the nine difficulty levels before playing, then you are ready to shoot at enemies coming from the top of the screen. Depending on enemies, you can choose one of the three weapons: riffle, missile or grenade.
title: Battle Zone

description:
Sudoku 4 Kids is a handheld dedicated to Sudoku. It features a LCD display, two +/- buttons (to increment/decrement numbers), two control buttons (enter/cancel) and 4 arrow buttons to navigate.

Powered by two LR44 batteries (included), the game offers matrices of 9x9, 8x8, 6x6 and 4x4 cells. It also features three levels of difficulty: expert, intermediate or beginner. In this mode, when a wrong number is entered, it flashes. Expert or intermediate modes do not provide this help.
title: Sudoku 4 Kids

description:
Flight Game is a dedicated, plane-shaped, handheld console. It features 9 games:

  • Tank Fighting
  • Dragon Pearl
  • Shooting Game
  • Pinball Game
  • Galaxian Game
  • Car Racing Game
  • Cross the Fire Line Game
  • Ghost Hunter Game
  • Tetras Brick Game

Since the games also feature variations, levels and levels speeds, the ad-blurbs from the box says: "9999 games in 1". Inside the box, jack headphones are included for "free". This electronic game is part of Premier Portfolio's Fun Plane range of travel toys.
title: Flight Game

description: Zap! is a reflex game in which two players compete in returning a signal between the two halves of the device. The longer they wait with returning it the faster it will be bounced back, but with the added risk of returning it too late and losing a point.
title: Zap!

description: Electronic Quarterback is an American Football game. There are two difficulties: beginner and pro. The player can try a running play and use the arrow keys to move the carrier and blockers in formation across the screen. Each line represents one yard. Players from the other team must be avoided. The player can also move the receiver and pass defenders in an attempt to catch a pass. On the 4th down a kick can be attempted for a field goal.
title: Electronic Quarterback

description: Digits is a Mastermind variant using digits. The player must guess the four number code devised by the computer and gets clues after each guess consisting of the amount of numbers in the right location and the amount of numbers that are in the code but in another location. A keypad is used to insert numbers. Other keys are for clearing input, guessing (submitting the input), giving up and restarting.
title: Digits

description:
Speak & Spell is an educational handheld device which allows children to play games that teach spelling and pronunciation. It's the first low-cost mass-produced consumer electronics using synthesized speech. Aside from speaking the words there's also a display that can display their spelling. The basic device comes with various activities to learn pronunciation and spelling and has one game "Mystery Word". Mystery Word is a Hangman-style word guessing game in which the game is over after seven wrong letters guessed. The clue key can be used to get a free letter.

The device comes with a word list of about 200 words and is expandable with new word lists of which multiple were released over the years:

  • Vowel Power
  • Super Stumpers 4-6
  • Super Stumpers 7-8
  • Basic Builders
  • Mighty Verbs
  • Vowel Power (UK spelling)
  • Mighty Verbs (UK spelling)
  • Homonum Heroes
  • Noun Endings
  • Magnificent Modifiers
  • Vowel Ventures
  • E.T. Fantasy Module
  • Les Mots de Base Module No 1 (French)
  • Les Mots de Base Module No 2 (French)
  • Les Animaux Familiers Module No 3 (French)
  • Les Magasins de la Rue Module No 4 (French)
  • Les Extra-Terrestres Module No 5 (French)
  • SuperModulo (Italian)
title: Speak & Spell

description: Baseball is a dedicated handheld which allows the player to engage in the sports of baseball. The play area has pre-painted graphics with a number of led lights showing the position of the players and ball. Numbers at the top of the device mimic the score board showing the inning, number of outs, balls and strikes. There are buttons to pitch, bat, run and view the score. After pitching the ball will be shown flying towards the base and the player must hit the batting key at the right moment. A switch allows to change between two difficulties.
title: Baseball

description: Basketball is a dedicated handheld that features a LED display with a pre-painted basketball court. LED lights show the locations of the players and a score field at the bottom displays the current remaining time or score. There are two difficulties and the player uses the arrow buttons to move the players around the field. The player is on offense and must score as many points as possible within 24 seconds. A total game lasts 10 minutes and is further divided into four quarters. There are two difficulty levels. The player can play against another player, but this is using hot-seat, where players take turns playing a quarter for the offensive and the defensive is done by the computer. In the Classic Basketball re-release it's possible to score a 3-pointer, this is not the case in the original. The re-release also uses LCD for the display rather than LED.
title: Basketball

description: Football II is a sequel to Football. It builds upon the gameplay established by the first game with some additional options such as running backwards and passing. Aside from the two difficulties that the original game also had it's also possible to go to hidden third and fourth difficulties by holding the pass button while selecting the difficulty. The original version uses an LED display, the later re-release uses an LCD display.
title: Football II

description: Hockey is a dedicated handheld that features a LED display with a pre-painted ice hockey field. LED lights show the locations of the players and a score field at the bottom displays the current remaining time or score. There are two difficulties and the player uses the arrow buttons to move the players around the field. The player is on offense and must score as many points as possible within the three periods. There are two difficulty levels. The player can play against another player, but this is using hot-seat, where players take turns playing a period for the offensive and the defensive is done by the computer. In some regional releases it's not possible to move behind the goal. The key-chain re-release uses LCD for the display rather than LED.
title: Hockey

description: Soccer is a dedicated handheld that features a LED display with a pre-painted soccer field. LED lights show the locations of the players and a score field at the bottom displays the current remaining time or score. There are two difficulties and the player uses the arrow buttons to move the players around the field. The player is on offense and must score as many points as possible. There are two difficulty levels. The player can play against another player, but this is using hot-seat, where players take turns playing a quarter for the offensive and the defensive is done by the computer. The key chain re-release uses LCD for the display rather than LED.
title: Soccer

description: Sub Chase places the player in command of a destroyer chasing a submarine. The submarine isn't visible but can detect proximity based on sonar signals indicated by a beeping sound the handheld device emits. The player can move the destroyer in four directions and use the fire button to drop a depth charge. The player wins a point if the depth charge hits the submarine and loses the game when a torpedo fired by the submarine hits the player. The player starts with 30 depth charges, the game is also over when running out. New submarines will spawn for each submarine destroyed.
title: Sub Chase

description: Armor Battle is a combat game where the player controls a tank and must destroy as many tanks possible within a time limit. After each successful hit the game stops and a new enemy is added. The player can move the tank in four directions with the arrow keys. Firing follows the same logic, but while holding the fire button. When next to an enemy tank the player must fire quickly or the tank will destroy the player. There are also mines, the presence of which is made clear through a sharp buzz when getting close. Getting blown up makes the player restart at the starting position.
title: Armor Battle

description: Mind Boggler (originally released as Memoquiz in Belgium) is a dedicated handheld that plays a code cracking game. The codes can be three, four, or five digits long. After each guess the player receives clues which can be used to further deduce the code.
title: Mind Boggler

description: Dataman is an educational handheld device. It uses some of the component of the TI-45 calculator to play a number of games that aid the user in learning math. The activities include: Electro Flash a simple math practice, Wipe Out which has a timing component, Number Guesser, Force Out in which you must prevent ending at zero, and [?] where unknown equations can be entered.
title: Dataman

description: Mr. Challenger is an educational handheld device that aids the user in learning spelling through four different activities. In Mystery Word can be played with one or two players. The player on turn must guess a word in the fewest moves. The display shows the number of letters the word has and correctly guessed letters. Word Challenge has two players guess each other's word. Crazy Letters is a Simon Says variant using letters. Letter Guesser has the player guess a secret letter. After each guess on the screen another letter is shown and the secret letter will be in between your last guess and the other letter.
title: Mr. Challenger

description:
Math Marvel is an educational handheld game which is designed to teach the user basic math in a playful way. There are four activities as well as a little book with more activities that require using Math Marvel as an ordinary calculator. The electronic activities are: Numberific which shows math problems in which a number is missing, the player is graded. Flash is a practice mode for basic arithmetic. In Zap music will sound after a random amount of time. The player who holds the device at that moment loses. To pass on the device to another player an addition must be solved correctly. In Quest a hidden number between 9 and 100 must be guessed by the player, the display shows the bounds within the number must be based on the wrong guesses and a higher/lower routine.

The calculator also has a mode where the entire calculation must be entered and the device will simply tell if it's correct or not. It's also possible to create your own custom exercise.
title: Math Marvel

description: Baseball, also released as Basketball, Bowling, Football, Hockey and Space Shot is a handheld game with a simple LED display. All versions of the game, despite of the thematic sticker on the device play exactly the same. Gameplay is simple and mostly chance based. The player presses the play button and lights will randomly go on or off. The player has to keep score manually using a mechanical score wheel.
title: Baseball

description: Raceway is a game very similar to Mattel's Auto Race. While gameplay is similar the layout of the device is completely different. Instead of a slider the device uses a wheel and also the slider is more in theme shaped like a throttle stick. The race track is shown horizontally instead of vertically with the lap and time display shown above. Gameplay remains identical with the player avoiding collision with incoming LED lights on the three different lanes while trying to throttle faster and faster.
title: Raceway

description: Electronic Master Mind is the official handheld version of the code-cracking game Master Mind. The player plays against the computer and guesses codes of up to five digits. The device displays the number of digits correctly guessed and/or in the correct location. The game comes with a paper notepad and pencil to aid the player.
title: Electronic Master Mind

description: The Incredible Hulk Escapes is a simple handheld game which is mostly based on random luck. The player presses a button to which different lights will light up leading to different scores. The scores need to be counted up manually and added to the score wheel while the Hulk climbs higher and higher. The game can be played with two players. The game is functionally identical to The Amazing Spider-Man Rescue.
title: The Incredible Hulk Escapes

description: The Amazing Spider-Man Rescue is a simple handheld game which is mostly based on random luck. The player presses a button to which different lights will light up leading to different scores. The scores need to be counted up manually and added to the score wheel while Spider-Man climbs higher and higher. The game can be played with two players. The game is functionally identical to The Incredible Hulk Escapes.
title: The Amazing Spider-Man Rescue

description: This game is designed for Ages 4 to 6 and aids children in counting, adding and subtracting going as high as the number 30. The gameplay has two modes consisting of the Learn Mode and the Quiz Mode. In the Learn Mode, the player does sums step by step. In the Quiz Mode, the player is challenged to correctly answer sums within a certain time.
title: Reader Rabbit: Beginner Addition

description: The Pixel Stars Digital Dreamhouse is a small handheld game similar to a virtual pet except that here, the being you must take care of is a human woman. The plastic case looks like a beach house, the front of which slides up to reveal a 1.3-inch, 240 x 240 resolution color LCD screen. The player can choose between controlling a Celebrity Chef, a Social Media Star or a Fashion Designer, with a special mini game unique to each character that is used to make money and acquire more items for the character's house. The home starts off with four rooms, but can be expanded up to 32 total. Each room can be decorated with items purchased from a catalog, and it's even possible to adopt a pet. The player is also charged with keeping the girls healthy and happy by making sure they are fed, bathed and rested. However, unlike most virtual pets, the girls will not get sick or die.
title: Pixel Stars Digital Dreamhouse

description:
Tamagotchi On is an update to the famous Tamagotchi series of virtual pets that adds in Bluetooth connectivity so the creature can now communicate with the corresponding app on a smartphone. The device, like all Tamagotchi units, is shaped like an egg, albeit larger than previous units at 2.5 inches tall with a 2.25-inch color screen. The user will hatch an egg and raise the young My Tama to adulthood by feeding it, showing it affection and playing mini-games with it. There are in-universe places for the My Tama to visit like a park and the store, where more items for the creature's house can be purchased. As the player interacts with the game in various ways, more locations can be unlocked.

The unit can connect to other Tamagotchi On devices in its immediate vicinity via an infrared sensor at the top; one creature can visit another for a friendly playdate, or the two creatures can mate to create an entire new My Tama with traits of both its parents. This creature can also be bred and so on to create successive generations.

The "Fairy" unit has a special land with a fairy theme that the My Tama can visit, as well as two characters exclusive to the version that the player's My Tama can befriend or marry. To unlock it the player must set a particular background (Dreamy Living) and take their third-generation creature outside between 7am and 7:59am. The Fairy theme comes in pink and blue shells, but the units are otherwise identical.
title: Tamagotchi On: Fairy

description:
Tamagotchi On is an update to the famous Tamagotchi series of virtual pets that adds in Bluetooth connectivity so the creature can now communicate with the corresponding app on a smartphone. The device, like all Tamagotchi units, is shaped like an egg, albeit larger than previous units at 2.5 inches tall with a 2.25-inch color screen. The user will hatch an egg and raise the young My Tama to adulthood by feeding it, showing it affection and playing mini-games with it. There are in-universe places for the My Tama to visit like a park and the store, where more items for the creature's house can be purchased. As the player interacts with the game in certain ways, more locations can be unlocked.

The unit can connect to other Tamagotchi On devices in its immediate vicinity via an infrared sensor at the top; one creature can visit another for a friendly playdate, or the two creatures can mate to create an entire new My Tama with traits of both its parents. This creature can also be bred and so on to create successive generations.

The "Magic" unit has a special land with a magical theme that the My Tama can visit, as well as two characters exclusive to the version that the player's My Tama can befriend or marry. To unlock it the player must set a particular background (Magical Room) and take their third-generation creature into the backyard between 7pm and 7:59pm. The Magic theme comes in purple, green and white shells, but the units are otherwise identical.
title: Tamagotchi On: Magic

alternate_titles.title: Game & Watch Colour Screen: Super Mario Bros.

description:
Game & Watch Color Screen: Super Mario Bros. is a special rendition of a traditional Game & Watch dedicated handheld in commemoration of the 35th anniversary of Super Mario Bros.. Completely rebuilt from the ground up with a full-color LCD screen it contains the following games:

  • Super Mario Bros.
  • Super Mario Bros.: The Lost Levels
  • An updated version of Game & Watch: Ball featuring the likeness of Mario instead of Mr. Game & Watch

Like the original versions from the 1980's , this G&W also features the "Watch-function" and includes a digital clock with 35 Mario-themed easter-eggs and little touches.
title: Game & Watch Color Screen: Super Mario Bros.

description:
Bubble Bobble Pocket Player is an officially licensed handheld offering three games in the series:* Bubble Bobble

  • Bubble Bobble Part 2
  • Rainbow Islands

It is powered by 4 AAA batteries or a Micro-USB cable (both not included). The box contains a lanyard.
title: Bubble Bobble: Pocket Player

description:
